elements.label: That Old Nightmare...
elements.description: If I walk out far enough into the cold, with the Key-Bearer as my only light and guide, I might stray into a familiar dream - a dream that stinks of mud and ash. I should not go there; I cannot go back there. But there is something I must confront in that terrible place, waiting. [This card will remain until you choose to journey to it - but Allies will be unable to follow you, and you will not be able to leave until your purpose there is complete.]

elements.label: Sobibor
elements.description: A hell built by the hands of men alone; a hell I was set free from a year ago; a hell I have returned to, so I might face and kill the darkness lodged in my heart by one I hate above all others.

elements.label: Ruined Country
elements.description: A bleak barren of countryside. None who remain here do so out of choice or convenience. Yet, I might find a utility in that. [Strange enemies are abroad in this place, but you might also find useful opportunities and allies while here.]

elements.label: Ruined Country
elements.description: A bleak barren of countryside. None who remain here do so out of choice or convenience. Yet, I might find a utility in that. [Strange enemies are abroad in this place, but you might also find useful opportunities and allies while here.]

elements.label: Kaunas
elements.description: The Exile told me they had a friend in Kaunas with the Iron Wolf, years ago when they still reckoned with the Tally. 'An eater of corpses,' they told me. 'And a maker of passable pastries. I hope he is dead.'

elements.label: Kaunas
elements.description: The Iron Wolf courted the Black Eagle here, during the occupation, when the Germans came to take Lithuania early in the war. But that love withered on the vine when the SS decided it no longer needed a second fiddle to its efforts, and disbanded the party. Fascists always end up eating their own.

elements.label: Brest
elements.description: Old Brest lies uneasily at the banks of the Bug River. This is where Germans turned on the Soviet Union, and bloodshed here is laced with a venom that seems undeniably personal.

elements.label: Brest
elements.description: Brest has been the site of two bloody German victories: one against the Poles, who were swept away by the wave that was Barbarossa. The second was against Soviets, whom the Austrian saw fit to betray not two years after the striking of the pact with Stalin. Neither I nor the Red Army will permit them a third.

elements.label: Königsberg
elements.description: News of the slaughter at Nemmersdorf has caused many in Königsberg to flee the coming of the Red Army. They're right to run.

elements.label: Königsberg
elements.description: Autumn ages into a biting Winter at Königsberg. Generals Lasch and Chernyakhovsky play chess in the streets with riflemen and tanks and artillery pieces, but the game seems to yield no clear winner - not yet.

elements.label: Gdansk
elements.description: A three-sided battle erupts at Gdansk. There, the Germans, the Russians, and the Polish partisans fight one another, street to street and rooftop to rooftop. I am unsure who I'll fight once I arrive there, but I'm sure the right decision will make itself clear once I get some fresh blood on my hands.

elements.label: Gdansk
elements.description: The war was born here, when the Germans shed blood on Westerplatte. That was only five years ago - and yet, I feel as though I have suffered five lifetimes of pain since then. Now, fighting between the Soviets, the Polish Home Army, and the Wehrmacht advances like wildfire up the Vistula. More pain, then.

elements.label: Grudziadz
elements.description: A playground for the Einsatzkommandos sent in to facilitate Germanization of seized Polish lands. It would be a shame to leave their blood unspilled.

elements.label: Grudziadz
elements.description: Long before he ever chipped Ebrehel on Kyiv's Golden Gate (or was it the gate of the City Unbuilt?), the First King planted here the seed that would become his city on the Vistula. Then, when the castle was built, the Teutons raised the Solar cross over the ramparts and atop the walls. A different cross - a hooked cross - flies over Grudziadz, now. I will tear it down.

elements.label: Lodz
elements.description: The officials of the Reich say the that city's new, noble German name is 'Litzmannstadt,' but when I spill an enemy's blood here, they will say he died in Lodz.

elements.label: Lodz
elements.description: The Forge's furious fires transformed this place in the 19th century: industrialisation, inequity, strikes and revolts; cinemas and schools and underground newspapers. This century is different. Winter closes its fist around Lodz, and sickness wracks the ghetto. What fires of industry still burn here have been turned towards the purpose of the enemy.

elements.label: Warsaw
elements.description: A campaign of total annihilation in Warsaw: punishment for the uprising in the ghetto. The Germans endeavour not merely to kill and expel the people, but to pull the city down to its very last stone. Could they do it? Strike an entire city and her people from the face of the earth? The Wolf walks on the horizon, expecting an answer.

elements.label: Warsaw
elements.description: Snow gathers on the bones of the royal residence in the bombed-out ruin of Castle Square. A blackened pile of books smoulders at the shattered mouth of Zaluski Library, where the brandkommandos have been at their work. So fresh is the blood of the August Uprising, I swear that I can still hear the screams of Polish partisans ringing off the stones. Block by block, street by street, the Germans are erasing the city of Warsaw.

elements.label: Lublin
elements.description: I remember I had relatives in Lublin, before the war. A wind tugs at my coat, and I wonder where those relatives are now. I wonder if they escaped, or were imprisoned, or were shot. I wonder if they became ashes, and if those ashes had already blown past me on a westward wind.

elements.label: Lublin
elements.description: Shadows lie long on the Grodzka Gate, which, for centuries, permitted the passage of goods, people, and ideas between the Solar and Jewish parts of the city. But now, one who crosses the gate's threshold will find the shop windows in the Jewish district are all broken, and the houses are all empty. On the outskirts of the city, a train whistles departure, and leaves for Majdanek.

elements.label: Katowice
elements.description: The fighting in the south outskirts has not reached Katowice proper yet, but Soviet tanks gather on the hills. By the time we get to the city, I suspect the downtown suburbs will have already been reduced to a forest of rubble and detritus.

elements.label: Katowice
elements.description: A Gestapo man was shot to death here a few weeks ago, and the Germans are still guillotining suspects in Market Square. The Polish rebels of the Home Army remember Bloody Monday.

elements.label: Kraków
elements.description: The Exile once reminisced to me about a man they knew in Krakow: 'Yitzchok was a smart one, and a good customer. I wonder if he was able to leave Poland before things became... untenable for his people.' He spoke of this Yitzchok with sympathy - but the kind of sympathy one offers a sick pet, and not a human being.

elements.label: Kraków
elements.description: On the hill above, the Governor-General lays out his wretched designs for removal and liquidation behind the walls of seized Wawel Castle. Below, in the Kraków Ghetto, a shivering child dreams of the karpatka her grandmother would bake when Autumn made the Sundays grow chilly.

elements.label: Vienna
elements.description: The White City. 'There's a Ligeian there, and she's lived there a very long time,' the Exile told me. 'The grumpiest of the seven, I always thought. But you'll want to see her, regardless. Tell her I said hello.'

elements.label: Vienna
elements.description: I played concertos here, once, in that faraway life before the war. My memories of that distant time - of applause and music and white-black keys at my fingers - those memories were carved out of me by the one called Exile. Now, the charred ruin of the Musikverein is the only thing left to mark that those impossibilities had ever been real.

elements.label: Brno
elements.description: Artillery pounds along the city's eastern approach. Soviets and Germans do battle in and around this jewel of Moravia, two starving dogs fighting over a shred of meat.

elements.label: Brno
elements.description: The President's university is empty, and the fairgrounds derelict. A gallows stands in front of the Spilberk Castle. The First Republic is gone; these are the days of the Occupation.

elements.label: Prague
elements.description: Chamberlain vainly offered Czechoslovakia up to the Reich, hoping to pacify the monster by feeding it morsels. His plan failed, as we all now know. But simmerings of resentment still burn across the country, and in Prague, especially. Someone with a match could turn this uneasy balance into a conflagration all too easily.

elements.label: Prague
elements.description: Notorious times in Prague. The occupation, the bombings, the raising of the ghetto. Even that godawful Austrian came here on parade, years ago. But the Hangman was killed here, when a Czech assassin's grenade ripped through half his body and left him dying slow. Good things still happen, sometimes.

elements.label: Liberec
elements.description: Wretched Henlein plays governor for the Reichsgau in ailing Liberec - his reward for supporting the annexation even before Chamberlain and Daladier handed Czechoslovakia to the Austrian. Someone should have rewarded him with a bullet, instead. Better late than never.

elements.label: Liberec
elements.description: The burnt-out ruin of the Old Synagogue stands against the blue sky like a jagged ribcage of unalloyed night. When the sun sets, it is almost invisible to the naked eye. But I can feel the heat of the fire still, as if the place had not stopped burning for five years.

elements.label: Dresden
elements.description: Not so long ago, the British and American air fleet came through here, and bombed the city to nothing. What was left was consumed in the firestorm left by the Allied air raids. The stench of sulphur, smoke, and ozone drifts off Dresden's corpse for miles.

elements.label: Dresden
elements.description: A figure in sandstone smiles from his perch on high, kindly and motionless. Below, the jigsaw-wreck of the bombed city does not return his cheer, and is quiet.

elements.label: Wroclaw
elements.description: Caught between the advance of the Red Army and the hand of winter, many of Wroclaw's civilians decided to take their chances running - and lost. The road to the city proper is littered with the bodies of the fleeing, snow gradually burying each gaunt, spiritless face.

elements.label: Wroclaw
elements.description: When the city was young, all manner of trade came here by way of the Via Regia and the Amber Road, and the Twins were known to watch the crossroads there. Time trampled those old roads to dust, and other Hours now walk in Wroclaw: Axe. Madrugad. And the Wolf.

elements.label: Poznan
elements.description: That contemptuous Austrian declared Poznan to be Festung: a stronghold city, and not to be lost. As if his declaration could hold back the Red Army's coming - or mine.

elements.label: Poznan
elements.description: On the outskirts and in the streets, the veterans who turned aside the Wehrmacht at Stalingrad cut down the enemy with grim persistence. Corpses pile up amongst the old Prussian fortifications. Breathe deep, and smell the death stewing in the air.

elements.label: Szczecin
elements.description: The city lies ahead, and bodies drift down the Oder River. I'll put many more in the water before I'm done in Szczecin.

elements.label: Szczecin
elements.description: The City of the Griffin, brought to heel by the talons of the Black Eagle. Allied bombing has scattered the old masonry of the industrial district into the waters of the Oder, but the Germans have fight left in them yet.

elements.label: Berlin
elements.description: The Reich's last death spasms wrack Berlin. All of us know it is over. But like starving dogs, the nations will pull and bite and gnash over who gets to devour the carcass. And I? I will have my day in Berlin, because I want to rip out the Reich's foetid heart and feel it crumple in my fist.

elements.label: Berlin
elements.description: Berlin is no longer a city, but an abattoir. On every street, an enemy; for every enemy, annihilation. If I slaughter enough, will I have, at last, my revenge? No - a world's worth of dead could not fill the emptiness the Wolf has set in me. But destiny's teeth - the Wolf's teeth - will not release me. Onwards, then. When dawn rises again on Berlin, I will know what destiny I have earned.
